title: EP 302 Daniel Mezick on Games and Governance

rawLines.text: Howdy, this is Jim Rut and this is the
Jim Rut
[Music]
show. Listeners have asked us to provide
pointers to some of the resources we
talk about on the show. We now have
links to books and articles referenced
in recent podcasts that are available on
our website. We also offer full
transcripts. Go to
jimrutshow.com. That's jimrutshow.com.
Today's guest is Dan Mesi. He's been
coaching executives and teams since
2006. He's a Scrum at Scale trainer and
he's an expert on business agility. He's
also the author of three books on
organizational change. And as usual,
we'll have links to those books on the
episode page at
jimrutshow.com. Welcome back, Dan. Glad
to be here, James. Thanks for having me.
Yeah, it's good to have you back. You've
been on the show a few times, most
recently in episode 151 where we talked
about ritual and
hierarchy. Today we're going to talk
about games and governance. Uh this
should be interesting. I believe it's a
very deep and wide topic that it'll, you
know, really be of great interest to
your listeners. Jim, let's start off by
what you mean by games. Why games and
governance? What the hell? Isn't
governance a serious thing? Isn't games
a frivolous thing? Uh tell me why we
want to talk about games and governance.
Yeah. Well, if you look up games, you're
going to find like uh seven noun
definitions and five verb definitions.
So, the whole topic of game is uh you
know, not really buttoned down. It's not
really clear. We have very imprecise
language about what gaming is. But
there's a book from a woman named Jane
McGonagal called Reality is Broken. It's
quite a long book. But the most
interesting part of that book to me is
page 22 where she defines the four
properties of a good game. And the first
property is all games have
goals. The second property is all games
have rules. The third property is all
games have a way of tracking your
progress. And the fourth property is
optin
participation consent of the governed.
if you will. So I think she did humanity
a great service, Jim, when she defined
for everyone everywhere all kinds of
games. She defined a definition that
applies, it's concise and it applies to
all games. So if we look at what she did
there, we could look at uh this meeting
as a game. We could look at any meeting
as a game. We could look at every
interaction as a game in the most
classical megonal defined sense of that
term. And when we look at like the
constitution, I see it as a infinite
mutable game about civilization, right?
So, so it's a largecale game definition,
the the US Constitution.
So if we really look at it, we can see
that it's all about who decides what. So
what we're really getting down to in the
constitution is who has

and in what domains and under what

really super interesting. And you know

Dunar's numbered groups handle this

decision, right? Who decides what under

us one of your definitions that a game

gets us back to the uh enlightenment uh

always point out that in reality, if

really opted into the constitution. it
kind of something that you have to take
or leave or you have to explicitly exit
if you don't want to play by those
rules. Maybe you could address that just
a little bit. Now that's fair. Let's
look at the ideals and then the
practical the practicality, right? So
the ideal is and and they talk about
this when they use the term consent to
the governed, right?
The ideal is that people are not under
compulsion in the way that they're
governed and they are in fact choosing
to submit to that form of governance and
the way that authorities distributed in
that in that schema. Now, of course,
someone born naturally in the country is
can't decide anything. First of all,
they're they're too young and secondly,
if they're born into it, you know,
they're subject to the rules, right? So,
this is a practical end of it. But the
ideal is that human beings don't like to
be pushed around and you can't get
anything done with people that are
unwilling. So this whole idea of
willingly submitting to the rules of the
game is a very interesting topic. So for

right? And you know, basically we're
trying to deceive our other opponents
into handing us their money, right? Yet
we all agree to the rules. So there's
membership in the rules. There's
camaraderie in the shared agreement
about what the hell we're doing at this
table with these cards, right? And and
this is a really important part of uh
being human is having a sense of
membership and belonging, right? So when
we all submit to the same set of rules,
there's belonging in those rules.
There's membership. We have something
shared. There's something common.
There's a basis for a culture. On the
other hand, and I think this is
interesting, it's playing this analogy
of the game. If the the players
operating the game are cheating or not
operating in good faith in the interests
of everybody, you have the right to flip
the game over and say, "Fuck the game."
Right. Yeah. And so, you know, this is
basically the power of revolution. the
people can at any time rise up and throw

it's difficult and dangerous, but it's

of the govern that, you know, in

of course, that's what's happening now.
If you look at the measurements of

Yes. One interesting fact to note about

what's really interesting about triad,

that it's highly
unstable, right? Because two can gang up

personal theory about it that when any

interestingly when it comes to design of

triarchy three founders or if you come

anybody married knows that, right? Two
people can have communications problems,
but if you have that third route, you
can basically continue communications
flowing even if individuals have diatic

to uh our three branches of
government. They can ally with each

though they typically don't ally, which
is kind of interesting. Anyway, this is

overall even though components of it are

between the two parents and the child.
And of course, the parents gang up on
the child and get the child to submit to
their authority, hopefully before
they're three years old, so they don't
get out of hand later when they're 15.
But this whole idea of the triad is
super interesting. And there's a fellow
named Dave Logan who wrote a book called
Tribal
Leadership where he actually described
uh how to use triads in business where

What is it? What is its purpose? And you

Yes. So the best definition I have for

deciding for the group is some of the
most important work that we could do.
Right? So there's all kinds of different
work. One of them is deciding. And of

super impactful and work that affects

That's how they define it. How does that

define granted to whom by whom? Right.
Yes. So, one of the things I often talk

Another way of saying I believe what you

uh either could be formal or informal.

we're trying to sell General Motors and

Right. It could be formal. could

there's nothing you can do about it.
That's right. That's right. And she

they end somehow. So football games end

Infinite games go on theoretically

There is mutability all up and down the

It's constantly a series of micro

a super interesting topic that doesn't

And he actually invented a practical

how long have you been married? Be 44

who's has no experience with romance
that these games are mutable, right? And
they're they're mutable at small scale
